name: Havening Techniques
summary: A psychosensory therapeutic approach that uses touch, eye movements, and visualization to reduce distressing emotions and reprocess traumatic memories.
description: Havening Techniques, also called Delta Wave Techniques, are a set of psychosensory interventions that aim to alter thought patterns and emotional responses through the application of soothing touch (typically on the arms, face, or hands), guided imagery, and distraction exercises. The method is designed to generate delta brain waves, promoting relaxation and neuroplastic changes. Havening is often used for trauma, anxiety, phobias, and stress management. It is considered a complementary therapy and is typically delivered by trained practitioners.

clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally considered safe and non-invasive; some clients may experience emotional discomfort during memory processing.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Emerging—growing anecdotal support, with limited controlled research studies.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Preliminary studies and clinical reports suggest benefits, but high-quality RCTs are limited.

sections.text: Havening Techniques utilize gentle touch, eye movements, and visualization to produce delta brain wave activity. This activity is thought to promote a sense of safety, relaxation, and memory reconsolidation, reducing the emotional intensity of traumatic or distressing memories. The soothing touch activates sensory pathways that help regulate the nervous system, while guided imagery and distraction aid in reprocessing maladaptive memory associations.

sections.preparation: The practitioner assesses suitability and explains the process to the client, ensuring consent and safety.
procedure: Application of gentle, calming touch (arms, face, or hands) by self or practitioner.
Eye movements and affirmations may be incorporated.
Reprocessing of distressing memories or reducing stress response.
sections.frequency: As needed—may be used for single-event trauma or as part of ongoing therapy.
sections.total_treatment_time: 1–6 sessions for specific issues; longer for complex trauma.

sections.pre_session: Client shares goals and identifies distressing memory or stressor.
sections.treatment_phase: Havening touch combined with guided imagery, affirmations, and/or eye movements.
sections.post_session: Client reflects on changes in emotional intensity; practitioner reinforces safety and grounding.

rare: Worsening of symptoms if trauma is not adequately supported

relative: Unwillingness to engage in touch-based therapy

ideal_candidates: Individuals seeking relief from trauma, stress, or phobias
Clients open to complementary and touch-based interventions

practitioner: Certified Havening practitioner (trained in psychosensory therapy techniques)

studies: Preliminary case studies suggest reductions in PTSD and anxiety symptoms.
Anecdotal clinical reports describe rapid symptom relief and improved stress resilience.
sections.limitations: Limited peer-reviewed, large-scale studies; more rigorous research is needed.

sections.insurance_coverage: Rarely covered—usually considered a complementary therapy
sections.cost_effectiveness: Potentially cost-effective due to rapid results reported in some cases.

sections.children: Can be adapted with parental support; used for fears and anxieties.
sections.adolescents: Beneficial for stress and trauma-related issues.
sections.older-adults: May help with grief, loss, and stress management.

items: Often positioned as a complement, not replacement, to evidence-based trauma therapies.
Requires careful screening for trauma sensitivity.
Can be practiced as 'self-havening' with training.
